facts.description: Mars, the fourth planet from the Sun, is a dusty, cold, desert world with a thin atmosphere. It has seasons, polar ice caps, extinct volcanoes, canyons, and weather patterns.

size.comparison: If Earth were the size of a nickel, Mars would be about as big as a raspberry.

orbital.eccentricity: Mars has an elliptical orbit, causing its seasons to vary in length.

rotation.seasons: Mars has seasons like Earth, but they are longer due to its extended orbit.

temperature.description: Mars has a wide temperature range due to its thin atmosphere, with daytime temperatures reaching up to 20°C (68°F) and nighttime temperatures dropping to as low as -153°C (-225°F).

environment.potential_for_life: Mars is unlikely to support life today, but scientists are looking for signs of past life when it had liquid water and a thicker atmosphere.

atmosphere.description: Mars has a thin atmosphere mostly composed of carbon dioxide, with traces of nitrogen and argon.

features: Olympus Mons – the largest volcano in the solar system
Valles Marineris – a canyon stretching over 3,000 miles
Ancient river valleys, lakebeds, and evidence of past water flows
surface.appearance: Mars appears red due to iron minerals in the soil oxidizing (rusting), though its surface also shows shades of brown, gold, and tan.
surface.water: Water is found as ice under the surface in polar regions, and there is evidence of briny water flowing seasonally.

moons.description: Mars has two small, irregularly shaped moons, Phobos and Deimos, which may be captured asteroids.

rings.description: Mars has no rings, but Phobos may break apart and form a ring in about 50 million years.

magnetosphere.description: Mars does not have a global magnetic field, but parts of its crust are highly magnetized, indicating a past magnetic field.

formation.description: Mars formed from the same cloud of gas and dust that created the rest of the solar system.

namesake.mythology: Named after the Roman god of war due to its reddish color, reminiscent of blood. Other cultures also named Mars for its red appearance.
